ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: A deeper knowledge of photography, outside of the technical aspect, but more within the art aspect and finding an artist's voice.
I learned a lot more about other artists' work and improved my own picture making skills and creative process.
I learned about photo composition and focused on putting photos in series.
I learned more about creating a body of work and being more deliberate with my photography.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course started to suffer from being virtual towards the end of the term as I think everyone (prof included) was getting a little tired of the long zoom classes, but overall it was a great course. There was lots of time to work on our projects during class which was helpful as the term picked up.
This class was as good as it could have been remotely.

strengths: Ted is very affirming and helps students create deeper and more meaningful work, he also brought in photo books and other media to help us have the opportunity to look at work. I appreciated how from the beginning he wanted us to be deliberate and work toward creating a project.
my only regret is that i really wish I could've taken this course in person

Work periods were incredibly helpful. Being allowed to continue developing work during class time and having the opportunity to ask the professor questions while doing so was very helpful in advancing photographs.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Giving us space to go out during class time to photograph was always helpful. Made me more enthusiastic about the class and it made me more present when we were on zoom.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely! Ted is a gem who really wants to help you develop as a photographer. He is caring but is also willing to push you to further your skills.
Yes! Ted is incredible and really cares about his students.
I would absolutely recommend this course. It is a great course to take after introductory photography and will allow you to further develop your skills.
yes, ted is really helpful and gives you critique and feedback in a way that builds you up rather than breaks you down.
Yes absolutely. Ted is a great teacher and cares deeply about the students he works with and the art that they produce.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
